resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
pitrou opened a new pull request #10480:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/10480


   When trying to read an invalid Feather file, the `stackprinter` project
   would crash when walking the stack and attempting to print detailed information
   about captured local variables.
   
   Specifically, the crash would occur when looking up the `version` attribute
   on the half-initialized FeatherReader object.


--

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #10480:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/10480#issuecomment-856769998


   Looks good.
   
   We have a similar pattern in `_parquet.pyx` ParquetReader, which is used in parquet.ParquetFile, and you can also get this to crash:
   
   ```
   In [7]: from pyarrow.parquet import ParquetReader
   
   In [8]: ParquetReader()
   Out[8]: <pyarrow._parquet.ParquetReader at 0x7f635377b280>
   
   In [9]: reader = ParquetReader()
   
   In [10]: reader.schema_arrow
   Segmentation fault (core dumped)
   ```
   


--

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
I'm trying to read a 0 byte file, probably erroneously written. This results in "ipython terminated by signal SIGSEGV (Address boundary error)", which could probably be more gracefully handled

 

https://ml-pull.s3.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com/job_desc_address_boundary_error.feather
fields.summary: [Python] Address boundary error with invalid Feather file and stackprinter

comments.body: Can you post the code you used to read the file?

I tried with the same versions as you (Pandas 1.2.4, PyArrow 4.0.1) and I get a regular exception:
{code:python}
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> pd.read_feather("empty")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<ipython-input-2-db70840ca427>", line 1, in <module>
    pd.read_feather("empty")
  File "/home/antoine/t/venv-3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pandas/io/feather_format.py", line 127, in read_feather
    return feather.read_feather(
  File "/home/antoine/t/venv-3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyarrow/feather.py", line 216, in read_feather
    return (read_table(source, columns=columns, memory_map=memory_map)
  File "/home/antoine/t/venv-3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyarrow/feather.py", line 238, in read_table
    reader.open(source, use_memory_map=memory_map)
  File "pyarrow/feather.pxi", line 67, in pyarrow.lib.FeatherReader.open
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 141, in pyarrow.lib.pyarrow_internal_check_status
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 97, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
ArrowInvalid: File is too small to be a well-formed file
{code}

How did you install PyArrow? Using pip/conda? What is your OS and environment?
It is installed using pip. It's on a Fedora 34 x64 workstation.

Well, that's weird. Can you double-check you don't have two PyArrow versions installed or any other such weird issue?

Also, are you able to get a gdb backtrace of the crash?
I narrowed the problem down. When running with python, I get the same error as you, but with IPython 7.21.0 I get the address boundary error
Can you also inspect {{sys.path}} and {{pyarrow.__file__}} under IPython to see whether you may have different versions of PyArrow on your Python path?

```

[ins] In [1]: import sys

[ins] In [2]: import pyarrow

[ins] In [3]: sys.path
Out[3]: 
['/home/ftdb/anaconda3/bin',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python38.zip',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/lib-dynload',
 '',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/Ftools',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/FxComparison',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/Sheets',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/DbMan',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/MortgageComparison',
 '/storage/code/fintechdb/Jobs',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/locket-0.2.1-py3.8.egg',
 '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/IPython/extensions',
 '/home/ftdb/.ipython']

[ins] In [4]: pyarrow.__file__
Out[4]: '/home/ftdb/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyarrow/__init__.py'

```
Ok, I don't know what may be misbehaving here. [~jorisvandenbossche]  any idea?

Also not directly an idea (also can't reproduce it locally in IPython with the same versions of pandas/pyarrow). Maybe additional check : can you show the output of {{pyarrow.show_versions()}} in IPython (and maybe also in python to see if there is a difference)

To come back to Antoine's earlier question: are you able to get a gdb backtrace of the crash?  
You could start with doing {{import faulthandler; faulthandler.enable()}} in IPython before reading the file (although that doesn't always give much more information)

I think this is due to `stackprinter`. Have a look at [https://github.com/cknd/stackprinter/issues/48.|https://github.com/cknd/stackprinter/issues/48]

 

Stackprinter was auto enabled in all IPython scripts for me, but not when run by plain Python. I'm confident this is a stackprinter issue, though I have never run into this problem except when trying to read a 0-byte file with feather. Strange

Ok, there's a crash which can be reproduced without stackprinter:
{code:python}
>>> from pyarrow import _feather
>>> r = _feather.FeatherReader()
>>> r.open("empty")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<ipython-input-3-fe5085a0421f>", line 1, in <module>
    r.open("empty")
  File "pyarrow/_feather.pyx", line 80, in pyarrow._feather.FeatherReader.open
    self.reader = GetResultValue(CFeatherReader.Open(reader))
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 141, in pyarrow.lib.pyarrow_internal_check_status
    return check_status(status)
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 97, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
    raise ArrowInvalid(message)
ArrowInvalid: File is too small to be a well-formed file

>>> r.version
Erreur de segmentation (core dumped)
{code}
